item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:19, topic:529276”]date’s default constructor is

public Date() { this(System.currentTimeMillis()); }
if users want to create a new object (which gives flexibility with the amount of methods used in the date class, then sobeit.

date.after() is a lot easier to calculate than the math.[/quote]

I’d say that it’s actually harder to calculate, because you’re probably going to be saving a Unix timestamp rather than a date object to the player file, so it would be easier to just check if the current timestamp is higher than the saved timestamp, rather than creating two date objects and then using the method.

item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

long currentUnixTimestamp = System.currentTimeMillis() / 1000L; if(currentUnixTime > player.chestUnlockTimestamp) { player.chestUnlockTimestamp = (currentUnixTime + 86400); for(int item : chestItems) { player.addItem(item, 1); } return; } player.sendMessage("You have opened that chest within the last 24 hours. You have " + ((player.chestUnlockTimestamp - currentUnixTime) / 60) + " minutes remaining.");

There’s really no need to use a Date object when you could use a Unix timestamp instead (easier to save).
